Early Access Review
								*UPDATE 12-24-2016* Well looks like Red Level Games is avoiding steam at all costs, with no updates to the game I would call this game development dead.  Apparently the devs are still updating people on Kickstarter (But I haven't heard of any builds being updated) so now my only guess is Red Level Games are trying to save face.  So looks like Dragon the Game is just another failed Early Access story.  Just add it to the pile.TL;DR version:Kickstarter campaign has (expensive) stage walls for some of the features below.  Game hasn't really improved in a year.  To my disapointment, it's to risky to pay 18 dollars.   Long version:I purchased this game the first day of release, I wanted the final product to be a decent indie game.   Sure it would have flaws but it would be enjoyable at least.  When I first booted up the game boy was in for a surprise... not for how far along the team was in developing this game, instead for how little and broken everything was; flying was awful, the camera was confusing to use, there was little to do, and everything about the visuals was just ugly.  At first I figure; this game is in early development and it's just needs more work, no worries I'll just watch it develop over time.  However over a year later and I would be lying if I said things got better.  Sure they did add some new NPCs, some new sturctures.  However flying is still broken, the scale of your dragon to the world seems off, and the game doesn't feel anymore improved.  So normally I would brush this game off as a bad purchase and I would have learned a lesson, or maybe still give the dev team the benefit of the doubt.  I honestly don't know that much about game development, so maybe there is more stuff under the hood they are working on that we just don't see yet.  The main problem for me is.  Even after being on the Steam store for over a year.  Red Level Games has decided to start a campaign on Kickstarter.  (To be honest I think they are the only ones to have started on Steam, then moved to Kickstarter.  I know the reverse happens or maybe even they launch at the same time)  It seems really strange to me.  I know games cost money to make, you need to keep people employeed in order to work on a game, you also need a place for them work.  I get it and I don't care that they have this campaign of the side for people who want to help some more.  My real issue is, some of the features listed below (As of the date of writing this review) are now suddenly blocked off by a stage wall.  Even though their Kickstarter Goal is 30K some of the features such as; adding more Dragon body types/species is a 750K milestone on their Kickstarter. I don't know what Red Level Games was thinking.  This game isn't really popular, it isn't really drawing the attention needed for a Kickstarter to get the majority of it's milestone/stages funded.  It's only popular in a niche market, so the people who would have been willing to donate to the kickstarter probably have already purchased the game and even a smaller percentage of them will  be willing to give even more of their money to this project.After this Kickstarter I'm now worries on the progress that will be made here.  I feel like it would be a huge risk to anyone now to spend 18 dollars on this game.  However all of this could work out, the game gets finished and it's amazing.  I would be so overjoyed and woul gladly admit I'm wrong.  It's just from where I'm sitting right now... I don't have high hopes.

Early Access Review
								I understand that this game is in early access, but I don't know if it's worth the money. I'm glad I spent it so they can work on it some more, but I'm having doubts. This game definitely has a cool idea, but it's not quite ready for anyone to play right now. In fact, there's almost nothing to do but fly around. Don't get me wrong, I absolutely love the dragon concept, but I don't know if they have a good enough foundation to get this off the ground (I made a pun because the dragon can barely get off the ground). Here are some ideas to make this game awesome:1. Better flight controls - It's very clunky and full of bugs. I found this nifty little nook on the top of a mountain and I tried to get to it, but my dragon kept falling backwards for some reason. No idea why. I would like to see something like Zelda: Skyward Sword. The birds in the game had very simple, but easy to use flight controls. Flap the wings, they'd go up. If you were high enough, you could coast on the "wind". I'm not looking for realistic, I'm looking for fun.2. Better ground movement - Dragons are mythical creatures, so I can't never know for sure...but I'm fairly certain that they aren't supposed to move like that. Also the body of the dragon doesn't interact well with the ground, and I'd like some motivation not to crash my animal into the ground. So far, the only way that's possible to land your dragon from high up is to do a death spiral to the ground. 3. More interesting landscape - I get that they are trying to be realistic, but I'd almost prefer if they focused more on mechanics and less on landscape. Plus, the mountains are kind of boring at this point. In the future, I'd like to see snow on top of them, and forests so thick with trees that it is almost impossible to land among. Also, rivers and lakes.4. Dragon Territory and Hoard- I think the game makers are going for a territorial/combat/choose your destiny kind of game. I'd like to see some caves where I can store all my treasure and princesses. 5. Better dragon customization - enough said. I'm glad I have an option to explore as a silver dragon, but I'd like a little more detail than that. Once again, I understand that this is a work in progress. But they aren't moving very fast and I don't know if they have the foundation for this to succeed. I will remain hopeful, however. So buy the game if you can afford it, but think of it like a donation right now because it's not much of a game at all currently.

Early Access Review
								******DISCLAIMER******** I don't recommend this game for specific groups of gamers. Please read the full review for my thoughts! thank you!This game is difficult for me to review, and I'll explain why. I have dreamt of this game concept for YEARS. I have told all my friends about this "idea" I had about a game where you played AS a dragon. Where the game was a mix of RPG/Action/Strategy/Open World/Co-op and PvP. A game where you started off as a baby dragon, heading out into the world. You would set up a lair, and then proceed to level up and grow as you saw fit. Maybe you'd be a typical giant red dragon breathing fire on all the nearby villages. Or you could be a diplomatic dragon who forged alliances with humans instead. Each level would allow you to customize and upgrade various aspects of your dragon. Etc...I could go on all day about my ideas (Been thinking about them for years as I mentioned.) Reading the description from the developers, this game COULD potentially BE my dream game, finally realized.On the one hand, I want to enthusiastically recommend this game so more people will support it and it can grow into the game of my dreams. However, I have to be honest and tell people what they are getting into before they spend their hard-earned money. I have barely started the game up, and quit after a minute or so because the controls were so un-intuitive and I couldn't figure out how to switch them. The graphics were poor, and no amount of messing with the settings would improve them. Obviously this is still in early access, so there is still hope for lots of improvement. With such a limited amount of experience in the game, I can't talk about any of the deeper mechanics, etc...but the small amount I did experience was hard to endure. I am planning to not ask for a refund in the hopes that this game will continue to grow and adapt into a game I can love. I bought it on sale for $15 ish, normally it goes for $17.99 I think. If you love dragons like I do (and like the developers, from the sound of it) this game could very well be worth supporting. If you're kind of "meh" on the subject of dragons, maybe wait a few months before purchasing.I will continually check up on this game and revise my review as time goes on. Thank you for reading!END OF OFFICIAL REVIEWTo the developers: (if they read these things...)Thank you for doing this game! As I mentioned, I have pictured this game in my head for 10+ years now! I always toyed with the idea of submitting it to some developer, but figured it'd already been discussed and dropped, of that there wouldn't be much interest. Every few years, I'd do an internet search for "dragon games" to see if there was by chance a game that somewhat matched my ideas. None ever have until now! Happened upon your game in a STEAM sale and bought it pretty quickly. I understand that this game is a side endeavor for all of you, outside of your regular jobs, so it can't be your main focus. All I ask is that you do what you (reasonably) can to make this game great! I could die a happy man if this game is able to fulfill even some of my grand dragon aspirations. Again, thank you for undertaking this project.

Early Access Review
								**Updated 4-1-16**The last time i played this game was 11-7-14. At that time it was little better than a tech demo.I have redownloaded the game. This is my new impressions.I'm going to compare what was, to what is now:(Note, i played on "good" setting for graphics).The UI prior - Seem to be well made for the starting screen where you pick your dragon/map and hit the play button. The background was equally nice. Over all, I liked it. When picking your dragon you could look at stats and what could be skills/powers. Detailed, very easy to read. This alone I'd say was very well put together and awesome at that.The UI now - The starting screen where you pick your dragon. First impression... Green neon grass/ground. Picking your dragon button over lapped the play button so all you can see of play is LAY. Which is fine since you can put together that it is a play button. Picking dragons, the details of the dragons you can pick from are lost on the right side fo the screen into the neon green color. Leaving you guessing as to what it is saying.. I think i saw the word Ox for one of the dragons.. not sure what that would be.. maybe fav food? Really not sure what happened here. Hard to read, buttons over lapping. Step down from last time i played. Real disappointment. Almost feels like they went backwards here.Map prior - poorly put together, could tell it was either rushed, or someone new to map making had put it together. Lots of seems where you could see the parts that were put together. Things would randomly fall through or if they walked into a seam, they'd fall through. Going too far in one direction would unload the map from where you were. Once unloaded, the map wouldn't reload. You were left with "dead zones" where you couldn't go back to them. Few trees. Villagers and their homes were bunched together like small villages (this is a plus). Over all, really drove home the feel that the game was a Tech Demo.Map Now - Improved, smooth, no seams, nothing falling through the floor. Map doesn't unload and fail to load again when you come back. Rather odd coloring, kind of a neon green or off green for the "grass". More trees. Trees look nicer now. Villagers do not appear to live very close together. Takes away from the feel of villages. Over all, makes the game feel like an Alpha so a step up for sure.Mobs prior - Few villagers, chicks with swords and guys with pitch forks (and of course the villager of doom, but he was a bug/glitch), cyclops, wolves, ents (or where they giants?). AI wasn't that good, simple see and attack. Passive mobs, cows, sheep. Easy to kill.Mobs now - Same types of villagers, plus man at arms (or what i'd call them since they had shields), Didn't play long enough to find many other types of mobs. But i did take note there are now deer, and rabbits. Wolves are still in. AI is still rather basic. Though now they don't all attack on sight (but should in cases like the wolves who sat there and let me fry them for one of the quests)Dragon Prior - Going to be honest here. The dragon we had access to when i first played was awesome looking. Really made me think Dragon. Handled ok, would go lopsided every once in a while. Could even change it's face a little.Dragon now - While it does offer i think premade dragons? Not sure as it wouldn't let me actually pick anything. I was able to change the color of my dragon with sliders. Didn't have that option prior. You could make a pink dragon if you wanted to now. However, the body of the dragon as well as head leave me thinking lizard then dragon. They did it the right way the first time. Though to be fair, i heard we'll be able to have more control over what our dragons look like... hopefully. Otherwise I'd say a step backwards here with the shape.Quests prior - there were zero quests.Quests now - very simple quests at first. I didn't put a lot of time in this time around, but i get the feeling the questions are going to become more and more involved.Combat prior - We had claw/fire to use for weapons. Pretty simple to be honest. shoot some fire, or hit them with your claws. I never found any bugs or problems with it when i played then.Combat now - Able to use fire or a tail whip. Tail whip doesn't always seem to hit. Fire will fly off into the distance and cross the map. I found this out by ranging in the direction i had sent some flames doing the quest to find a chest. Actually seems more buggy then it did prior.Over all prior - I felt the game was a tech demo and nothing more. I wouldn't have recommended the game to anyone, but didn't want to leave a poor review as it's not a finished game. I wanted to wait until the game is finished, then give it a real review that may or may not be positive.Over all now - I don't feel like the game is a tech demo anymore. If i were to gage it's "age", i'd say it's early to mid Alpha. It's gettingn a lot of factors together now. The map is for sure cleaned up. Just needs more TLC. Combat and UI needs some heavy work. The game does though seem to flow better. There are some real possibilities for this game if it ever gets finished. Do I recommend the game? My answer is still sadly no. Not because it's an early Alpha after 1.5 yrs. Nor because of the remaining bugs, and unfinshed features. It's not even the snails pace it seems this game is being developed at. The reason why I am not willing to recommend this game is simple. Commuication. The developers made a promise to maintain that with us. They failed to keep their promise. I will not move my recommend to a not. Because the game is not finished. As such, there is still a chance the dev's will turn it around yet again. But we'll see how that goes. I will be uninstalling the game now. I'll load it up again when there appears to be either some heavy updates or the game is finished or in another 1.5 years ;) Which ever comes first.**old review**First, I am not recommending that anyone buy this game.I am putting it as a recommend as there is no middle choice. Right now i'm waiting to see where the game goes.The idea of the game.. oh my god, it's awesome, what it could be is fantastic... but fantasy and reality don't go hand in hand. What will come out of this game is by far not set in stone yet.Currently the game play is little better than a tech demo of a game. Bug filled, not very pretty graphic wise and lacking in content. You can fly around as a dragon, and haphazardly attack things with either fire, or melee. You can fly, and burn stuff. That is what is currently available in the game, plus bugs, lots of bugs, tons of bugs, map disappearing and not reloading, suddenly flying with a tilt, etc.To be perfectly honest here. Only buy this game if you want to support the dev's and take a change on if this game will go anywhere or not. It's been out since Nov 7th of 2014, their last update to the game (not counting the testing updates that you can opt into, was in Jun of 2015. They did have some updates before then. They have been working on the game according to the opt in option. However, being one of the people who didn't opt into it, i wouldn't know what sort of "testing" is going on, and based off of the forum posts of actual testers... there doesn't appear to be that much to be impressed with. So, if you like the idea, and want to try to help out the devs... then by all means buy the game. But do so knowing that at this point in the development, you're taking a shot in the dark as to if there will be any sort of pay off (aka finished game) or not.I bought on the first day it was released onto Early Access. While I'm disappointed that i don't have much of a game yet to play, i do have hope and currently do not regert buying the game.I will update this review once the game has something to show for itself other than a tech demo style of game.

								At this point, I can't recommend this as an early access title. It's probably one of the three crowdfunded titles I actually regret purchasing. In the last two years, very little has changed in the actual product. While there might be "under the hood" work being done, there is also very little communication from the developer despite numerous requests for information. The last round of customer complaints on lack of updates elicited a post from the developer where he stated "I can communicate more regularly and authentically."This was on July 10th.It's now nearly two months later, and not a single post or bit of information has come from the developers. It could be a deserted project sitting in early access for all I know, but there is no communication present.Even before this, it was spotty - this started on steam EA and had a number of purchasers (I'd guess a few thousand). Then, after that initial open-up for purchase, there were a few updates, almost no communication from the devs, and then silence for several months afterward. Things became active again for a month with a Kickstarter which got another 50K to develop the game, a couple of updates during that time and then complete radio silence for 2-3 months. Until the people that purchased their game practically shook the cages asking what the hell was going on, can we hear anything at all about this project?When tracked down and found in a livestream, the developer stated they were afraid to communicate because of possible "misunderstandings". This is a pretty bad excuse. No one misunderstood anything, no one was being negative in their forums, just asking "can we get an update?" or "has this project been abandoned? I haven't seen any sort of communication."Bottom line, I urge you with all caution NOT to purchase this early-access title. Due to the lack of communication from the developers, the strange excuses, and the lack of overall progress over the period of two years, this is most likely not going to be finished, and any money or hopes put on this are likely to be a wasted effort. I do expect another round of crowd-funding before they finally go totally dark and abandon it, but the pattern has been pretty clear since this project started.If the behavior actually changes, then I'll be happy to update the review. At this point, though, buyer beware. They don't have enough personnel or resources in order to make the project they are selling.

Patch 8.3 Review UpdateI reinstalled the game to check out the latest beta patch. I wrote my previous review months ago, but now I figure it's time to come back and readdress some things with a bit more clarity.I purchased this early access game in April 2015. It is now currently January 2016. There have been very little changes since I bought it. Certainly not enough to "wow" me yet.The Positives1) Previously, I made mention that the flight controls were sickeningly sensitive to the point of being out-of-control insane. With the 8.3 update, it's not as bad. I was able to move without throwing up in the process. That is one thing I can say has noticeably improved. It was so terrible before that I couldn't play the game at all.2) The terrain seems more lush than before. All I remember was long stretches of blank ground with barely any trees or mountains or much of anything.3) You can grab people and animals and carry them into the air and eat them. If you can manage to get it to work properly, that is. I'll get to that later.4) You can now color the dragon. This wasn't an option before.5) Flying around in circles is fun, even if I'm not really doing anything important. So, ponts for being immersive.The Negatives1) They said the optimization was improved, but it still seemed pretty poor on various settings. The funny thing is, the lag and stuttering happens the most when running on the ground, and it's smooth sailing (no pun intended) when you're flying over miles of forests. This happened to me before the patch, as well, on the fastest graphics setting on a brand new gaming machine with a more-than-capable graphics card. This needs some serious tweaking before it's playable for a wider range of people.2) While the flight controls were easier to deal with, the other controls were a bit of a mess. I tried like hell to pick up people off the ground in mid-flight. I managed to successfully do it once, then proceeded to drop said human because I'm spamming the Q button like crazy trying to snatch him up. It barely works. I was more excited than I needed to be when I finally managed to get it.For some reason, the flight controls were automatically selected as inverted when I reinstalled and restarted the game. I'm used to normal flight controls. This isn't a big complaint, because that's an option you can change.Grabbing things will sometimes just bug out the dragon or the enemy you're picking up to where they're almost melting together like in The Thing.3) The envrionment is hilariously glitchy, as are the enemies and objects. While flying the dragon around, I couldn't count how many rocks, trees, tree stumps, houses and people were either stuck halfway through the ground and peeking up through a mound of snow like they got trapped in a snowbank, or were floating in mid-air like they were caught in a time-warp. I almost don't want to call this a "negative" because I laughed whenever I saw it. I actually got stuck underneath a floating rock at some point.Sometimes you'll get stuck on a piece of the terrain-- say, a house or a tree-- and you'll suddenly and mysteriously get launched backward several yards as if you had been rocketed off of a pine tree trebuchet. This also made me laugh. "Where are you going, Dranonimous?!" I yelled.The LOD is a mind trip. In the distance, the envrionment is just one giant oil paint color blotch, which really negates the look of the piece of the map you're currently standing in. It makes you think that if you go anywhere near the color blotch, you'll disappear into the gaming void. I didn't want to go past the borders of the snowy forest, which I figured was the least glitchy part of the map. I did fly somewhat away form it to check out a badly-rendered lake. Then I turned back because the rest of the map had also turned into a lake somehow. 4) I never lost any health. Or gained any. I don't think you can really get hurt yet. I understand that eating is meant to replenish you, but that doesn't seem to have a purpose. Not yet, anyway. And your enemies are clones of one pitchfork-wielding dude and cows. Or cottages.5) Maybe I'm not the first to say this. If I am the first to say it, then let it be known: The dragon... is ugly. I'm sorry. But it just is.The dragon's front arms look like they should be socketed on a G.I. Joe. The back legs belong to some kind of alien frog. The head... well, I can barely look at it, because whenever I try to, the dragon shoves his face in the ground like an ostrich. The tail is three times as long as its body.The running and flying animations aren't very fluid. Instead of running on its bulging soldier arms and amphibious hind legs, it does this sort of "hop" that really reinforces the whole "Frog" concept. Maybe there'd be a different animation for walking, which would follow the stride of most other four-legged creatures. Right now, it just looks awkward and weird and not at all aesthetically pleasing.The flight animations aren't much better. The body is sort of stiff as its airborne, sans the waving, flapping tail, and the wings resemble cardboard.Final ThoughtsOverall, my opinion is mixed. It's starting to show a tiny bit of potential, but the updates have not been very grand since I bought this, and they state it should be ready for release and out of Early Access in two years (and they said this when I bought it). Yeeeah, I don't think so.Dragon The Game is in VERY EARLY ALPHA, and this should be considered when making the Early Access purchase. It is barely even half ready after nine months. With how slow the game is updated, and the lack of massive improvements, I'd say it would take more than two years to make this game bug-free and good enough to buy.Does that mean you shouldn't support it? Eh. If you think it'll go anywhere, be my guest. I still feel like my money hasn't gone to anything worthwhile.

Early Access Review
								I will update this review with each successive update to the game.If you find this review unhelpful, tell me why and I will try to fix it.Revised 7-8-2016Overview: It is evident from the blog and other resources that the focus right now is on game function and code stability, mostly under the hood stuff, the kind of stuff that matters much more than how pretty it looks. Nobody gives a damn about your Corvette if there is no working engine, and nobody cares about a game with underdeveloped code. In that regard I think Red Level has its priorities straight, and in the play-through my priority at this phase in development was to look at code stability, controls, and interface. Stability and Control score a solid OK, it took me only about five minutes to figure out the basics of movement and flight and after ten was able to fly around without crashing into anything. Movement & Controll: For those thinking of buying now, the dragon maneuvers like you are flying a helicopter, gravity is irrelevant once you hit the space-bar and continues to be irrelevant after you let go, which causes you to slowly float back down to the surface. A The W key allows forward flight, with a momentum dynamic like you would logically expect. Turning is instant and mouse directed, but you will tend to drift like a Ford on ice while cornering even if your dragon faces the desired direction instantly so plan ahead. Be aware that the game does not bind the mouse to the game screen, so long turns in one direction will cause the mouse to drift off screen and will close the window when you click any mouse button.Combat: Combat is very one sided, both in terms of damage taken, and physical damage dealt since you can only swing your tail to one side or your dragon, so make sure the thing you want to kill is on that side. Fire breath is hard to aim at first so be careful using it on the ground or you will burn yourself before anything around you. Think like an airplane when using this, you want to strafe a target with fire if you can, before landing to collect it.Navigation: As of right now navigation is line of sight only, you get a look at a map sketch when you first drop in to the game but you have no mini-map in your interface so plan on getting lost. Right now having your bearings doesn't really matter since there is not all that much to do. .Quests/Tasks: The quest system did not load during my most recent playthrough and is likely being rewritten.Interface: Currently you get three small circles in the lower right had corner of the screen which tell you what powers or attacks you have. There are "Roar" "Tail Swipe" "Bite Attack" and "Fire Breath". Roar did not provide audio feedback when used, and I could not observe any notable effect to things on the surface. Tail Swipe/Fire Breath controls are functional though there are some quarks to be resolved as the game progresses. A Three button mouse is needed to use both bite and tailswing. There is a hunger readout on the bottom right which gives access to the upgrade menu which is currently in development and not working. A new menu tree is in process which looks promising.Graphics: Vast improvements to terrain and graphics quality were included in the most recent update. The framework is there for high poly models but they have not been applied yet.Sound: Mostly placeholder sounds, they have good ambient noises but the looping soundtrack can be a bit annoying. Improvements to come, but likely not until after Alpha.Secondary Effects: In shooters this would be like bullet holes where you shoot walls, or dynamic destructible vehicles. In dragon this is most notable with fire breath, where your fire can spread from one part of a building to the whole. You can burn down trees, or knock them over with your tail.Physics: Physics modeling for a dragon in flight is helicopter based, you will drift in the direction you are leaning when not using the throttle. Glide dynamics have been added, but gravity is weak for your dragon and allows for unrealastic floating, and are now fall/impact deaths for you or NPC's, but collision mapping is buggy and can cause models to drop through. The glide dynamic has improved somewhat with the most recent update, and is being dialed in progressively.AI: Villagers become hostile when you get close enough, and are harder to kill. They will always take the shortest route to you, and will stack up beneath you if you fly just right. Animals are neutral, (except for bears) but will run away if you get too close. The recent update has reduced the amound of ambient wildlife, making eating more difficult.Stability: Beta, not optimized. You will have low frame rates regardless of your system power. I maxed out at 32FPS but dropped as low as 12 at near max graphics, which did not strain my system. Pre 3-29 update I was lucky to get 12FPS max, so there is improvement. There have been a series of small un-announced updates which have improved overall stability.Glitches: A quick twenty minutes of game play did not result in any crashes or game breaking glitches. I did not get stuck in a cave, or get caught under the map. When grabbing objects you are almost guaranteed to experience a glitch known as the "runaway rag-doll". This glitch can happen as a result of poor collision mapping, or can occur if the engine thinks the object its grabbing is weightless and therefore has no inertia. You get an explosion of flailing limbs that can be distracting, but that’s about it.Another prominent glitch occurs when two animated objects collide on uneven or akward terrain, resulting in one or both objects being thrown violently out of map or straight into the air. This glitch occurs in nearly every game in development, and was made popular by Skyrim's "hammer spike" in which being killed by an overhead swing from a giant launched your character straight up into the air. You will see this in Dragon if you land directly on a live deer or wolf. Sometimes the both of you are thrown, or sometimes only one of you. This is more likely to happen on hillsides or in rocky terrain. It also happens if you tail swing a sheep, deer, or wolf into another object without killing them, resulting in a violent but non lethal vertical launch.Developer: Red Level Games as an upstart has an opportunity to fill the general void left by developers like Bungie, EA, and even Microsoft. All of these companies have had rather lackluster recent releases that have underperformed in some way, they have become victims of their own success and now sell titles based on their franchise hype.Red Level Games has all the attributes of a good developer, they:1. Operate an independent website that isn't an eyesore, and was reasonably easy to navigate.2. Have an easy "contact us" section which allows anyone to email them directly.3. Post blog updates to their website and Steam (recently on a monthly basis)4. Allow the community to contribute to game mechanics where applicable.5. Are honest and forward in their efforts.6. Clearly communicate update goals and priorities.Dragon: The Game has great potential, especially if it allows the community to generate content and assist in building the product. They have already partly done so by releasing a model dragon skeleton for hobbyist animators to play with, and to potentially contribute to animation in game. They appear dedicated, and work in a fantasy niche that nobody has attempted to fill until now. For that reason, and the ones listed above, I can recommend this title to anyone who wants to support beta development. This means that you are willing to play a partally functional game and be a good sport about it untill things get fixed.

Early Access Review
								First off, I would just like to address that as the indicator states above, THIS IS AN EARLY ACCESS REVIEW, and will be assessed as such.Dragon: The Game has great potential, great conceptualization and fantastic ambition. The idea behind an open world MMORPG/RPG that puts you in the position of being one of several fully customizable dragonkin is an amazing push towards online gameplay and single player experiences alike. Putting you at the helm of fully designing, developing and modifying your dragon-sona is something that hasn't been seen in the field.However, the development team is relatively slow compared to similar major Early Access games such as StarBound or The Long Dark, and more importantly, THE PRICE FOR THE EARLY ACCESS IS RIDICULOUS. Yes, it's wonderful to contribute to new developers, as the gaming field is a large and quickly growing industry that should be open to anyone who so wishes to explore it, but $17.99 for a game that is currently unplayable is not appropriate.That said, it's hard to see why such a basic game in this current stage is suffering from such a dramatically poor run-state. As you will see in other reviews, along with my own input, you really do need a near top-of-the-line operating system. Don't be fooled by the pretty commonplace system requirements - I apologize for not being able to tell you exactly why it doesn't run, but the performance, even at literally bare minimum skeletal optimizations, runs at about 8 fps at best on your average to decent gaming computer or laptop.However, I still am very excited to see the completion of the game. I am hoping that this problem array be addressed so that the game doesn't get criticized and ridiculed, but rather fixed and allowed to live up to its full potential. I still support this game, but cannot recommend it at this point in time. I do however, recommend that you keep up with this game!

								I like the idea of this game.  It is a Dragon Sandbox, and if you played AD&D at all, or perhaps read some of those real popular novels in the late 80s that launched the Dragonlance franchise, the idea behind this game might appeal to you all the more.    Now, I am going to press <enter> and I'm going to indent so that you will see that there is an important point about to be made.  Please take the few seconds to read it.  Please don't skim.  I will refrain from using all caps this time.        This game is not in Alpha yet.  This game is not a game yet.   This game can only be called a work in progress at the moment     This game is very nebulous at the moment.  Be advised: if you to buy a complete Dragon: The Game, wait.   However, if you are  as intrigued as I was by the game concept as I was and wish to -contribute- and -invest- in the game's future, by all means, buy.  I think that the nebulous nature of the game at this point is a selling point.  Buying in now gives you a say, at the ground floor, in how the game develops.  I have ideas bubbling out of my ears, and you will find that many other people do as well if you look at the game Forums.  I envision a game that barely skirts getting sued for copyright infringement, where time tested (and gamer approved) Dragon Concepts are incorporated into the game (for instance, a set number of "Good" dragon colors and a set number of "Evil" dragon colors, as an example.  I will recomend this game for those that have the money to spend and want to help.  I do not recomend this game for those looking for another victory notch on their belt after they "beat" the game in twelve hours.   Just one last comment on the growing number of people that adding helpful, proactive posts on the forums for this game.    It's easy to gripe about a game's flaws.  But it is a far far better thing to actively help the devs and the players for no other reason than to see the nebulous become concrete.

Nothing you do in this game makes any difference, you might as well just do nothing at all.The only thing that seems like it might be a good idea is the concept of flight as you get to flap your own wings at your choice, this means you can control flight much better than other games where there is no difference piloting a flying animal and a jet plane. However the execution of this concept is underwhelming, it doesn't help that the flying animations are just goofy looking and mechanical.All in all, a very bad game and the developer excusing it calling out early access and alpha as some sort of excuse for the very poor quality this game has is an indication that this project will never see completion. The mechanics of the game are floaty and unappealing, the graphics are horrible, the textures are low resolution and just ugly, the effects for fire are amazingly bad (and this is a game where you'll be using fire as your main weapon mind you) and I say amazingly because there are free games out there that have better effects for fire. I don't believe this game will ever see completion and I do believe the developer is getting more money than he/she deserves by careful editing of his game's trailer.If you pay 18 dollars for this game you're either a dumbass like I am or you're using your parent's credit card and you have no sense for value of money. There are 99 cent games for smartphones that have good graphics, solid gameplay and some even have campaigns with storylines. This game has none of those features. This game is the perfect example of how payed early access can backfire and why these kinds of games should not be allowed to exist by the people over at Steam.

Early Access Review
								When you purchase an Early Access game you are making a choice. A conscious choice to support and help fund the project, regardless of the potentially difficult road ahead. Early Access games are, obviously, games that are still in development. And every game that you happen to support will be in varying degrees of said development. It's inevitable that you may stumble upon something that is in it's fairly early stages. Others have brought up the length of time the game has stayed in development. I can assure you there are games that have had more funding which have been in Early Access for longer than D:TG. Most independent dev groups are small. They do not have the funding or the man power to pump out content as much as we may be used to with other titles. I've owned the game for some time. The progress has been sparse, but it's beginning to pick up speed. The team has been able to acquire better funding and they are beginning to push for content that we would like to see. It's likely that in the near future their team will grow and they will be able to produce better quality content at a much faster pace. Currently, I have to agree with some of the negative reviews. There's a lot of placeholder material, the control scheme is whack (very uncomfortable, but I believe they are aware of this), and there's not a lot to do. You run around, eat a few deer, and set some villages on fire. It's.. not entertaining. Controlling the dragon with the mouse is just strange. I really wish there was a better way to manage one's camera and flight mechanics.Yet regardless of my distaste I have high hopes for the future.The dev team seems passionate about this project. There's not many games out there like D:TG. It's kind of one of those titles we always wished for. But to make that happen we have to help support it. Constructive feedback is the most beneficial to all. Not some cheap jab at an obvious problem without offering any form of solution or critique. If we sit here and ♥♥♥♥♥ endlessly we're going to do nothing but doom the title ourselves, and then try to pass it off as the dev team's fault. It's a two way street with the commitment made with early access.They plan a lot for this game. I'm excited for the future.

content:

Early Access Review
								Since this game was just released as a super early♥♥♥♥♥alpha recently, it's not completed (obviously). There's not much to do and not much to see. It's a starting point and the devs are pretty keen on working on stuff (and did some pretty immediate bug fixes so that's a pretty good sign). Here's the preliminary barebones review, to be updated as the game does.UPDATED - NOVEMBER 12TH, 2014Notes: It's really hard to actually split some of these things into pros and cons at this stage of development because everything, depending on what you value or how 'done' it is could go in either category. Until the game is further along, I'll keep the various points in a numbered list here, irrespective of pro or con.ONTO THE THINGS--1. Lots of potential. You're in a sandbox world as a dragon and theoretically, you get to help shape the landscape (metaphorically). Hopefully before too long we'll be able to interact with humans, have enemies, etc. At the moment, as of the latest hotfix, there is a lot more life to the map. Humans (some that attack you with spears), cows, deer, trolls, move houses, lots of trees-- It's not much yet, but it's getting there, especially compared to what it was on release day.2. Graphics aren't half bad though not spectacular. A little dated at the moment. They'll probably get better and could use some optimization work (but so could the whole system and that typically comes with time). There are still some problems with screen resolutions and rendering, but killing something no longer causes the Peasant of Doom glitch (I.E. killing a peasant would cause them to erupt with red blood gibs that formed an FPS-murdering column to the point where you ought to restart your game and think about what you how murdering peasants is apparently bad). Also the status bars and some of the buttons (like the map selection button that looks a bit like a loading screen) could use some polish.3. Dragons are customizable and can age. While that's not fully implemented yet, it's on the way, bro. There is some current customization and stats (but they don't seem to have much effect at the moment). At the moment, customization is limited to changing colors, but entire different species of dragon and adaptations are planned.4. Linux and Mac versions.They were released pretty quickly along with the recent hotfix. There seems to have been some issues with getting the Linux version to play straight from Steam for some users, but the devs posted a workaround for it in the meantime while they fix up their Linux upload.5. Very active and respectable developers.They've been very active in the forums, very polite in how they handle criticism and feedback of all sorts, and have shown zero leaning towards any sort of censorship. They're chill with anyone wanting to review or add suggestions or doing letsplays. They're also working on cataloguing known bugs to quash as they can while working on implementing new mechanics. So far, they've been very on top of things and have been amicable. They are some of the best behaved Early Access developers I've ever run across.6. Unity engine. Not really a con unto itself so much as Unity can be a buggy pain but it can also do some cool stuff. There are people that really don't like the Unity engine. That's entirely fair. However, it can be done well. In the meantime, it's going to be its own pain in the♥♥♥♥♥while the devs work to tame it. It also just doesn't seem to like some computers which can be a real off-putter to some gamers.7. Nothing much at the moment to do. You can fly around (the mechanics of that were improved with the recent hotfix, but it can still be a bit wonky-- I'm bad at it and faceplant into the ground a lot). You can light things on fire, especially now that there's a lot more to burn: several villages from small to large (though some are unpopulated), a small amount of people (women with spears and screaming men), trees, and apparently trolls. You can also eat the gibs that drop to help you grow. Unfortunately, there's nothing more than that yet. That and the growth mechanic isn't exactly implemented yet either and it needs a lot of tweaking.8. The tutorial is virtually non-existent.A tutorial itself hasn't really been implemented but some helpful hints when you start a world are shown on the screen. Unfortunately, due to earlier mentioned resolution problems. There is a list of current controls pinned in the Steam forums, but that's another temporary workaround until things can be more solidly implemented.9. No save/load feature.When you start a world, you always start fresh. You cannot save and you cannot load. This is only temporary, but at the moment, there isn't much you'd want to save anyway. Your dragon's stats at the moment are carried over through the playthroughs anyway. Just every time you start the game, you basically refresh the map so you can burn the same villages over and over again.10. Pricy, somewhat. For the level of early access that it is, it's a bit high, but they made no pretense about how much it would be when they posted their pricing model in the forums here on Steam. However, in the long run and for being a part of the development process, that's not so bad. It just depends on what's worth it more to you, the customer, to pay now to be part of the development process or to pay later (at a possibly higher cost) when the game is more complete or entirely complete. The developers have stated that they are encouraging people who aren't sure or who have been burned by Early Access debaucles before to please wait to purchase until their trust can be earned.

								I'm going to post my little opinion about all this, cause I'm seeing so many jabs toward this game. My opinion on this game is that while it is kind of splayed out and awkward on many levels(and my computer can't really run it, but that's my graphics card, not really the game), I do like it. I see that this game can go somewhere. Yes, it's been a month and no update has happened, but think about it this way from the devs perspectives. Someone had to probably pay bills, someone probably got hurt, or someone became ill. These could lead to a major slow down in production. And hey, maybe they didn't wanna say anything about any of those possibilities because they didn't want us to worry about the games production, or maybe they're just waiting for the right moment to tell us something special. Who really knows? My thing is, I see so much negativity on these reviews from people who bought this game aside from the people who actually have valid points.The way I see it is, you bought this game because you were eager for something, right? This page on the right side clearly states in their description that this is an early access and is NOT complete. To dumb it down, yes it is unpolished. Yes, there are many bugs. Yes, you cannot do a lot other than fly around and kill stuff and take damage from your own fire. Expect it. Because they are still working out kinks, just very slowly. And hey, sometimes slow and steady wins the race right? Yes, that was cheesy, but it's true in some cases.I'm not trying to completely defend the developers on their slow progression(and yeah, it does sound like I am, doesn't it?), I'm just trying to say don't have completely high expectations. Because if you do, you're going to be stomping away all huffy puffy wondering where your $18 refund is. And I've seen a lot of reviews that start with "I know it's early alpha, buuut..." No buts. You bought the game. Therefore you "signed up" for it's underdevelopment and are willing to patiently see it through. No crying or whineing about how dumb and crummy it looks right now. If it's early alpha, expect some stuff to not look right. It just means the developers have to get to that at some point. They're not octopi.That's all I really have to say on the matter.LATER EDIT: As a message to those who are curious about this game and aren't interested in waiting month after month for an update for a game that does still have many glitches and settings that hardly make much of anything better, it's recommended that you guys wait. Trust me, you won't have to scream about a refund or say you got scammed. Save your money, and just keep an eye out for updates and maybe more positive reviews for reassurance. This game has potential, but it's got a long way to go. Only jump on the bandwagon if you know what you're getting into.

I can say, however, that the rest of the game was a blissful journey through neverland without feeling a sense of guilt that would have made hitler feel like a goody-two shoes, simply because there was no rest of the game. Perhaps with three more years of work it won't make Tōru Iwatani feel like his Pac-Man game was ages ahead of it's time. Early Access Review
								UPDATED: 14 November 2014First off, let me say that this game is in VERY Early Access. All you can really do at this time is fly around and flame some stuff, so if you're looking for a finished game, don't get this just yet. However, this game has a lot of potential, and at this point in time, looks very promising. How it goes from here depends on where the dev takes it, though they seem to genuinely enjoy doing this, so I have high hopes for how it comes out.I'll edit this as more content is released and the game is updated.Now, there are currently a number of bugs that are with the game (to be expected from early access) including:~The Exit button does not work (EDIT: The Exit button only seems to break if you delete a dragon)~If you delete a dragon after creating it, it will no longer let you choose/create new dragons, and you are stuck with the dragon you deleted. (EDIT: Completely deleting the "Dragon" folder in steam => steamapps => common folder on your C: drive (or wherever Steam installs itself to) and reinstalling the game seems to fix this).~After deleting the dragons and restarting the game, the "New World" is shaded out, until I tried to exit the game (which failed because the button was broken) and went back to the menu, where the New World option was available again, even though forcing me to play as the dragon I deleted.~There is also a case of extreme lag, especially when flaming people. (EDIT: It has been fixed, since now it isn't and endless fountain of food, but it still lags at least my game, even though it doesn't crash the game like it used to.)~An issue with the mouse staying inside of the window when in windowed mode~The camera runs a little high, especially when you land, and seems to get stuck on whatever position it had to go to when you landed.~Resolution problems, where changing the resolution affects the menus (at least in Windowed mode, not sure about fullscreen), making it difficult to navigate them because they do not size down with the res, or they compress to fit into the window without changing size, thus overlapping each other.~RPG elements are minimal, killing humans and "eating" the blocks they dropped increases your experience bar, even though I haven't found enough humans to get to the level up screen just yet.~Customization is minimal down to changing your dragon's color.~Perhaps moving the dragon closer to the screen when customizing so you can see them better, as well as enabling a sort of free look so as to be able to clearly see every part of the dragon you're customizing~A lot of very bad lag, don't know if it's my computer. But the moment the game starts to the monent it closes there is lag.Glitches aside, and despite its current minimal state as I'm playing it (14 Novemeber 2014 --- 7 Days after release) this game looks very promising and genuinely fun. I'm looking forward to where the devs take this.

								At this stage (being written as of 8.5), there are still bugs, but less than there was beforeSome oft these bugs may still exist, though, as i have yet to test them due to being stuck on the same maountainous world (more on that in bugs/issues). That being said, i'll leave past comments there, but they will be marked with "(8.04)" after them, and at the end of the section. Bugs/Issues ---YOU CANNOT QUIT THE GAME NOMALLY ONCE YOU'RE IN. Once you're in the game, the pause menu only brings up the new tabs (dragon, grow, hoard) and the options of "Resume," "Respawn," "Controls and Tips," and "Options." There is no option to quit. Looking at other screenshots of the game, all the menus are in the right places, but i think instead that it's the UI that isn't scaling correctly relative to the developer's resolution, resulting in either inaccesible or overlapping (or both) buttons.---If you choose to respawn, you'll be stuck at a loading screen for an indefinite amt of time (i sat at the loading screen after respawning for around 7 minutes)---Upon creating a dragon, no matter the kind, when looking at it in the selection screen, it will always show as a "Drake, Green Dragon" (the devs noted this in their update notes)---Even with the deletion of an old dragon and the creation of a new one, you still have the same hoard, the same stats, and spawn on the same map (regardless of which map you choose)---After picking my map for the first time, get used to it, because you will be stuck there FOREVER. -Even after reloading and selecting a different map, you will be sent to the same map you were just at.---The music/sound effects are quiet, and there are no volume options in the "Options" menu---You have to look directly at a target, so you don't know if it's dead or not (The only way i can tell is if the health ticker stops counting down, as well as the sound effects from said creature stopping)---there is no enemy health bar (which would be really useful)---enemies pile onto the center of your dragon, making them difficult, if not impossible to kill---trees still don't bleed---M3 (clicking the mousewheel) for tail bash doesn't work---what is M5? (for a fireball)---the funfacts at the loading screen pop by too fast to read it all accurately---you can't see the "Play" button on lower resolutions, but even on hiugher resolutions it is stacked under the "Your Dragons" button---Starving still has no consequence---having the ability to walk through small houses (8.04)---floating stuctures (8.04) But there are some good things! ---eating is no longer instantaneous---the day and night cycle is excellent and pretty---there is now a health counter (for yourself, at least)---you can no longer fly off the edge of the map---the map is of colossal and realistic size---animations are very smooth---fun combat (even with enemies climbing onto you, lol)---you no longer fly up faster than you fly forward---scrolling up in the "Grow" menu reveals money! One gold unit is 65 actual gold into your hoard, instantly. Be rich!---Hunger now depletes at a rate relative to what you're doing (standing, running, flying), and at a much more reasonable rate---no more glitching water (8.04)---swimming! (though your head is underwater) (8.04)---the developer(s) makes almost *no* contact with their community. we don't know if it's still being worked on, and (i feel) we have little input on the next features to be implemented/bugs to fix~I've not entered any cave yet (as none have spawned for me in either the past version or the current one)~I've also not experimented with the effects of weight and armors on flying and combatIt's exactly what it says to be—Dragon The Game. It is also still in early access, and the bugs listed in the first portion are accaptable (for now). And, unlike many other early access games i've heard of, the devs are still working on it (and from what i can tell, progress will only be getting faster from here!)It's an excellent game with immeasurable potential, and things will only get better from here.

								Feburary, 2015 was when I first gave this game a review. I gave it a thumbs up because it had potential.  Sadly I'm going to have to update this review, as of January 2017, and change it to a thumbs down only because I just remembered that I backed this disgrace on both Early Access and then on their (somehow successful) Kickstarter.I bought this game initially when it first crept onto Steam in Early Access form.  It was a little square of land floating in the endless void where you got to move around a shoddy looking dragon asset, fly around haphazardly and burn some villager and goblin assets.  Even then, in the most barebones, tech-demo-y existence of this game it was more playable then than it is now.  Let this sink in.Two years ago, the game was more stable than it is right now.These days, despite a few additions of enemies and ground textures, the game has made almost no positive changes.  But it has made changes.  Oh yes, the game's stability has actually degraded over the last year or so.  The dragon controls terribly, buttons simply do not work, commands are mapped to mouse buttons that don't exist on most commercial mice, enemies still try to kill you long after you killed or even ATE them, the game crashes frequently and such a simple looking game runs awful on even high end computers.  Did I mention there was, or might still be, an achievement that's granted if you go into a cave lair and get stuck there?  Because that's acceptable.  The lair isn't there anymore, to my knowledge.There is nothing redeeming here.  There's no fun gameplay loop here.  It's a herculean effort just to get the game to work on your computer. The thing that really stings the most is the complete lack of communication from the developers to their EA Steam community.  Long bouts of silence broken up by non-updates if the community got too silent and goes so far as to childishly insult its concerned stakeholders because they are rightfully upset about the product they might have double-dipped funds into in hopes it would become their dream dragon game.I really wanted this game to be good.  I still do, in fact!  But honestly, if its incredibly small but incredibly dedicated fanbase tried, they could probably make a far better game in half the time.Pros?  Nothing.  Cons?  Everything.  Avoid.  The Dragon Dream remains a dream, for now.This was my previous review in Feburary 2015:This game is very promising.  It's like a dragon egg starting to bump around and crack the shell.  From what I've seen of Red Level Games they seem to be passionate about the project and are using the funds they recieved already from Early Access to hire more people to their team.  Updates are oncoming and just had one recently to its beta client.  If you're looking for a finished game I obviously cannot reccomend it, but the game has a long way to go and the devs and players know it.  However, if you look at the money as an investment and you're really interested in seeing this project come into fruitation for the ultimate dragon game, then I'd give it a buy.  Flying around burning stuff is fun in its own right.  I find myself logging on occaisionally to the live client just to torch some goblins or townsfolk, while also attempting to break the stamina bar in order to continuously accelerate in the air, flying at Mach 2 before crashing into a mountain.  All I can say is, as of right now it's a mildly fun but flawed dragon flight simulator with some objects to torch.  But I hope that this game sticks it out in the longrun.
